content.question:
Name
 Structure
 <math alttext="K sub a at 25 degrees Celsius " overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>(at</mtext><mtext> 25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C)</mtext></mrow></math>

Acid 1

<math alttext="3.3 times 10 to the negative 2 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

Acid 2

<math alttext="1.9 times 10 to the negative 1 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.9</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

The table above provides information on two weak acids. Which of the following explains the difference in their acid strength?

choices.label: Acid 1 is a stronger acid because it has more acidic hydrogen atoms than acid 2.
Acid 1 is a stronger acid because it can make more hydrogen bonds than acid 2.
Acid 2 is a stronger acid because it is a larger, more polarizable molecule with stronger intermolecular forces than acid 1.

Acid 2 is a stronger acid because it has a more stable conjugate base than acid 1 due to the greater number of electronegative <math alttext="B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms.

content.answer: Acid 2 is a stronger acid because it has a more stable conjugate base than acid 1 due to the greater number of electronegative <math alttext="B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms.

topic.text: 8.6: Molecular Structure of Acids and Bases

skill.text: 6.C: Support a claim with evidence from representations or models at the particulate level, such as the structure of atoms and/or molecules.
